etymology.description: 看(看) (kàn, "look") + 看(看) (kàn, "look") indicates a repeated or brief action, often used to suggest casually looking at something.
etymology.interpretation: The repetition of 看(看) (kàn, "look") in 看看(看看) (kànkan, "look") conveys a sense of casually or briefly looking at something, not with intense focus but more out of curiosity or to check something quickly.

examples.english: Take a look at the book.

examples.chinese: 到公园时(到公園時)，你看看风景(你看看風景)。
examples.pinyin: Dào gōngyuán shí, nǐ kànkan fēngjǐng.
examples.english: When you get to the park, take a look at the scenery.

examples.chinese: 吃饭前(吃飯前)，先看看菜单(先看看菜單)。
examples.english: Before eating, first take a look at the menu.
